Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to log into the production server. The message was from my sister: “Can you come over? I really need to talk.” Her words were short, but I could sense the heaviness behind them. At the same time, my Slack was blowing up—alerts, frantic messages from QA, and a notification from my manager: “Production is down. Users are locked out. We need you to fix this ASAP.”

I stared at the screen, my mind racing. As a brother, I knew I should be there for my sister, especially when she reached out like this. We’d always promised to support each other, no matter what. But as a software developer, I was responsible for the code that had just failed hundreds of customers. The team was counting on me to troubleshoot and resolve the outage, and every minute lost meant more frustration for users and more pressure on my colleagues.

My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pulling me in opposite directions. I felt torn, guilty for even hesitating, and overwhelmed by the impossibility of being in two places at once.
